posts.cooked:
We need your opinion!!

The team wants to gain more height from the elevator and what seemed like a simple way to do this is make the inner (smallest) stage of our elevator smaller. For this example say 2 in shorter

The team canâ€™t decide on how much taller the elevator is going to actually get. We have worked out it will have to get taller so less than 0 is not an option. The crux of the problem is that the elevator is two stage. Here is a photo of the elevator stage that will be shortened for context.

Will the additional height of the elevator be:

4 in 2 in 0 in 0 voters

4 in 2 in 0 in

4 in

2 in

0 in

0 voters

0 voters

0 voters

Our team actually has no idea of what will happen so we are asking CD

posts.name: Arshon Bozorgi
posts.cooked:
making that stage smaller wonâ€™t gain you any height unless your mechanism is specifically mounted on the bottom.

otherwise changing the size of that stage will not affect the height unless the mounting point of whatever mechanism you have on there is moved higher also.

Edit after reading accepted solution: My response assumes that all stages already reach its maximum extention.

For more context elevator is from thrifty bot and the mechanism is going to be mounted somewhere on this grey frame attached to the inner stage image 1006Ã—1358 109 KB I have also gotten a value from the CAD I think is correct but I donâ€™t want to reveal it just yet

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I imagine itâ€™d be 4 inches. The top of the elevator is gonna be 2 inches higher and the bottom of the mechanism is going to be 2 inches closer to the top of the elevator.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Assuming a cascade lift, could be 0 or 4. You have 2 stages, so the change in travel of a stage is doubled, but if the first stage is at itâ€™s limit then no amount of carriage modifications will increase the extension. If this was rigged continuously, the extension of the stages do not need to be equal.
Can you send a photo of it fully extended?
First stage is not at its limit right now but its close This is the limiting factor for the 2 in number given
No photo unfortunately but I have a poorly shot video

posts.name: Steven Pearson
posts.cooked:
Your elevator stage will travel 2 inches more, but that doesnâ€™t mean you will gain 2 inches of height.

If your mechanism is mounted at the top of the elevator, it will start 2 inches lower, but end up at the same place.

If your mechanism is mounted at the bottom, it will start at the same place and end up 2 inches higher.

If itâ€™s mounted somewhere in between, youâ€™ll start somewhat lower and end up somewhat higher.

posts.name: Alex Kempen
posts.cooked:
Reducing the height of the carriage should result in 4 extra inches of height.

The height gain is multiplied by 2x since the carriage is rigged 1:1 with the first stage, so when the carriage itself is able to travel 2 more inches relative to the first stage, then the first stage will also travel 2 more inches.

The extra 2 inches the first stage travels is taken out of the overlap between the first stage and the base stage when the elevator is all the way up (in the same way the overlap between the carriage and the first stage is reduced by 2 inches).

This also means the overlap between each stage will remain the same, which is an intrinsic property of cascade elevators and is nice since equal overlap maximizes stability when the elevator is fully extended.

I assume you will properly adjust the rigging so the elevator still goes down all the way (which is something thatâ€™s fairly obvious to do).

If your mechanism is naively mounted to the top of your carriage, then itâ€™s possible you may lose 2 inches there. However, you can always simply adjust your mounting to compensate for this, and if your mechanism is mounted on a structure that is independent of your carriage (such as the rails you shared above), then this wonâ€™t affect you.

If anyone is still having trouble seeing where the extra 2 inches come from, think about what would happen if they decided to make their entire elevator 2 inches taller instead.
I cant find any flaws in this explanation and it agrees with the CAD. I think we will try to IRL just to get a final answer. Thanks for the time spent and explaining it so well.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
VenomousFire:

The extra 2 inches the first stage travels is taken out of the overlap between the first stage and the base stage when the elevator is all the way up

This is a potential (and perhaps likely) constraint that may limit the height gain of the inner stage relative to the base.  On a Thrifty elevator there is a crossmember on the base stage that holds anchors for the inner stage cascade rope.  It is possible depending on geometry that the rope pulleys on the bottom of the middle stage do not have 2 more inches they can travel before hitting the rope anchors.  If that is the case, the overall height gain will be limited to 2 times the additional height the middle stage can be raised relative to the base due to physical constraints.  It may be possible to modify the rope anchor design if the anchors constrain the movement, but this would need to be a part of the redesign.

There is also the issue that reducing the distance between the bearings on both stages increases the force on those bearings when the elevator experiences lateral loads.   Reducing a typical 6 inch span to 4 inches might not result in failure depending on the mass of the end effector on the elevator and how the robot accelerates with the elevator at various states of extension, but it increases the potential for failure.  This is where the question of can I make this change starts to intersect with the question of should I make this change.

We ran an internal pole and debated for a further 30min, and here are the results. image 480Ã—640 22.9 KB The vote is missing another 2" vote and includes a latin and chemistry teacher who were walking past.
